text.p: These are some of the leading stories in the official Vietnamese press on Tuesday. Reuters has not verified these stories and does not vouch for their accuracy.
-- Wages in Vietnam have fallen by 30 percent since 1993, despite government measures aimed at creating jobs and boosting growth, the National Assembly's Social Affairs Commission has reported.

-- Prime Minister Vo Van Kiet has promised help for rice farmers in southern Vietnam's flood-prone Mekong Delta. Kiet said the government would purchase all surplus grain ahead of the flood season to prevent future material losses, which this year have been estimated at more than $50 million.

-- Eight people have been killed, 15,000 families are in need of help and 3,000 hectares (7,400 acres) of paddy field have been seriously damaged in the southern coastal province of Kien Giang following the worst flash-flood in 30 years.

-- Delegates to the National Assembly have called for new measures to support farmers and agricultural production. Delegates also asked the Committee for Anti-Corruption and Smuggling to consider gifts of land and other valuable items as bribes.
-- Vietnam's Pacific Airlines will open a new passenger service between Ho Chi Minh City and Macau in November.
